Theory¶

Freely-jointed chain¶

One of the simplest models of the polymer is the freely-jointed chain.

Worm-Like Chain model¶

The work-like chain model may be viewed as the generalization of the freely-jointed chain model with the bond length \(b\rightarrow 0\).

The force-extension dependence in WLC model¶

The stretching of the WLC polymer results in reduction of conformational space available for the polymer.

The exact form of the \(F(d)\) dependency is not known. Most usually, the Marko-Siggia approximation is used (citation):

(1)¶\[F(d;L,p) = p\left( \frac{1}{4\cdot(1-\frac{d}{L})^2} - \frac{1}{4} + \frac{d}{L} \right)\]

The Marko-Siggia function commes from ... Because of the construction, Marko-Siggia function agrees well with experiment in low- and high-force regime. For the intermediate force up to 17% of discrepancy was reported (citation).

To decrease the error, some correction were proposed. In particular, the Petrosyan function:

(2)¶\[F(d;L,p) = p\left( \frac{1}{4\cdot(1-\frac{d}{L})^2} - \frac{1}{4} + \frac{d}{L} - 0.8\cdot(\frac{d}{L})^{2.15} \right)\]

was reported to decrease the error to 1% (citation).

Including the bond stretching¶

The theory of the Worm-Like chain model assumes that the polymer is not extendible. However, this is not the case in some real polymers. For example, upon stretching, the distances between the residues get stretched too. The same is observed in case of in silico coarse-grained analysis, where the beads representing the polymer are confined with (extensible) harmonic spring. To account for the stretching, the Elastic WLC model (eWLC) was introduced (citation).

In the eWLC, the expansion of the bond is included by introducing the elasticity \(k\). Then, the relative extension \(x\) is modified by the factor \(x \rightarrow x-\frac{F}{k}\):

(3)¶\[F(x;p,k) = p\left( \frac{1}{4\cdot(1-x+\frac{F}{k})^2} - \frac{1}{4} + x - \frac{F}{k} \right)\]

This simple modification is widely used e.g. in the analysis of stretching of DNA chains (citations). However, such modification remains constant regardless of the chain contour length. In fact, the chain with \(N_L\) bonds, each of the same spring constant \(k\), under the force \(F\) should exhibit additional expansion of \(N\cdot\frac{F}{k}\). Then, the contour length (the maximal extension of the chain) increases as:

(4)¶\[L \rightarrow L + N_L\cdot\frac{F}{k}\]

This should result in changing the WLC response as:

(5)¶\[F(d;L,p,k) = p\left( \frac{1}{4\cdot(1-\frac{d}{L + N_L\cdot\frac{F}{k}})^2} - \frac{1}{4} + \frac{d}{L + N_L\cdot\frac{F}{k}} \right)\]

This equation is rather unpleasant in manipulation, therefore, the extension can be expanded into series:

(6)¶\[\frac{d}{L + N_L\cdot\frac{F}{k}} = \frac{d}{L} \frac{1}{1 + \frac{N_LF}{Lk}} \simeq x\cdot(1-\frac{N_L}{L}\frac{F}{k})\]

as from definition \(L = N_l \cdot b\) where \(b\) is the bond length, the equation (5) can be presented as:

(7)¶\[F(x;p,k) = p\left( \frac{1}{4\cdot(1-x\cdot\left(1-b\frac{F}{k})\right)^2} - \frac{1}{4} + x\cdot\left(1-b\frac{F}{k}\right) \right)\]

This is the form of the stretch-adjusted wlc model introduced in the StretchMe package.

Influence of the linker¶

It is common, that the polymer of interest (e.g. protein) is attached to the beads which are pulled with a linker. The linker itself can also be a polymer (e.g. DNA), which could be modelled again by WLC model. In such a case, the system may be compared to a series of springs. As the force on each two ends of the spring is equal, the same force \(F\) stretches each spring. As a result, the total distension \(d\) registered in the system of a protein connected by two DNA linkers is equal:

\[d(F) = d_{DNA_1}(F,L_{DNA_1},p_{DNA_1},{DNA_1}) + d_{PROT}(F,L_{PROT},p_{PROT},k_{PROT}) + d_{DNA_2}(F,l_{DNA_2},p_{DNA_2},k_{DNA_2})\]

where \(L\) is the contour length, \(p\) persistence length, and \(k\) is elasticity. Usually, the DNA linkers on each side are identical in structure, therefore, their distensions are equal and one can neglect the last term, introducing the 'effective' parameters for DNA:

\[d(F) = d_{DNA}(F,L_{DNA},p_{DNA},{DNA}) + d_{PROT}(F,L_{PROT;i},p_{PROT},k_{PROT}) + d_{DNA}(F,l_{DNA},p_{DNA},k_{DNA})\]

Inverting the force-extension dependence¶

It is often needed to calculate the extension of the chain, knowing the force acting on it. This problem also does not have a analytic solution. Usually, one neglects the behavior of the chain for small forces, and inverts the strong-force regime part, where the extension scales as square root of the force:

(8)¶\[d(F;L,p_l) = L * \left(1-\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{Fp_L}{k_BT}}\right)\]

This approach is invalid outside the strong-force regime, e.g. when one protein state is ruptured in relatively low forces. However, the Marko-Siggia function, after reduction to a polynomial is cubic in \(d\) and therefore may be computationally easy inverted. Namely, the value of \(d(F;L,p,k)\) is the real root of the appropriate polynomial, lying in the interval \((0,L)\). The polynomials used are written explicitly in The exact form of functions used in StretchMe.

This approach is valid, as one can show, that the derivative of the Marko-Siggia function is strictly positive in the interval \((0,L)\), mapping the interval into positive real numbers (for positive \(p\) and \(k\)). Therefore, it is a bijection of these intervals, and therefore for each force there is only one \(d\) within this interval. In case of eWLC model, with non-zero elasticity \(k\) one needs to use the implicit function theorem Implicit Function Theorem.

Finding contour length¶

Usually, the contours are found by global fitting of the curves. In such approach, each trace has to be divided into parts corresponding to the states, and for each part a separate fitting of the contour length has to be done. In each fits, the persistence length and the elasticity has to be the same.

This approach fails, if the transitions between the states are not clear, i.e. the difference in contour length is small. Moreover, even after proper division of states, the number of parameters to be fitted is \(N+2\), where \(N\) is the number of states (\(N\) contour lengths, persistence length and elasticity). Each fitted parameter introduces own error, therefore, for a structures with only a few states, the results may not be reliable.

However, more important is the case when the polymer of choice (e.g. protein) is connected with the pulled bead with a linker (e.g. DNA). In such a case, usually one assumes, that in the first pulling phase only the linker is stretched. Then, one may fit the first phase obtaining the parameters of the linker and use it to subtract the linker impact on total extension \(d\). This method, however, fails if the polymer of interest is stretched simultaneously with the linker. Such situation happens e.g. when the protein connected with DNA linker has two, loosely bound subdomains. Then, the domains are stretched apart in the first pulling phase, along with the DNA.

To solve this problem, one may generalize the method proposed by Puchner (citation). In the original method, knowing the persistence length, one may invert the observed force to obtain the relative stretch \(x=\frac{d}{L}\) for each force registered. Next, one may plot the histogram of the values \(l=\frac{d}{x}\) i.e. the quotient of the extension \(d\) and the \(x\) calculated for the corresponding force. For the ideal measurement, these values should be equal one of the contour lengths \(L_i\). In reality, as both measured force \(F\) and measured extension \(d\) are subjected to some errors, the histogram plotted shows a set of picks, centered at the values \(L_i\). Therefore, this allows to obtain all the contour lengths \(L_i\) from the histogram, knowing only the persistence length. It is then straightforward to include also the elasticity \(k\), as it only changes the function, which has to be inverted in order to find the relative extension \(x\).

In practice, this method can be used to fit efficiently the traces, as it only requires fitting two parameters (persistence length and elasticity) to obtain all needed parameters, including the contour length \(L_i\). Now the question arises, when does the parameters fit the trace best? Assuming the Gaussian error in measurement of both forces and extensions, the relative extension \(x\) is also calculated roughly with Gaussian error. The quotient of two Gaussian distributions is a Cauchy distribution (Probability distributions). Therefore, for each pick, one may calculate the p-value, i.e. probability, that the resulting distribution comes from corresponding Cauchy distribution. Or even simpler, one can calculate the mean skewness of the picks, as the Cauchy distribution is symmetrical around its mean (has 0 skewness).

Observe also, that this technique in principle allows to deal with simultaneous stretching of polymer and linker, as in the pessimistic case it requires fitting of 5 parameters (3 for linker and 2 for polymer), but simultaneous stretching is not a problem.

The Dudko-Hummer-Szabo approach to state life-time¶

During polymers stretching, each state has a mechanical resistance, resulting in a characteristic distribution of forces needed to rupture the polymer, and as a result transfer it to the next state. Dudko, Hummer, and Szabo described the method, allowing to transform the distribution of forces to the lifetime of the states, and to calculate the energy barrier on rupture, as well as the stretch distance at which the rupture should occur (citation).

(9)¶\[\tau(F) = \tau_0 \left(1-\frac{\nu Fx \ddagger}{\Delta G\ddagger}\rigth)^{1-1/\nu} e^{-\Delta G\ddagger [1-(1-\nu Fx\ddagger/\Delta G\ddagger)^{1/v}]\]

The expected chain reduction upon knotting¶

Upon knotting, the maximum length of the chain (contour length) gets decreased compared to the unknotted, stretched chain, as a portion of the chain is used to create a knot.

The exact form of functions used in StretchMe¶

In the computations, the form of the \(F(d)\) dependencies are not suitable for calculations. In particular, usually the basic quantity is the relative extension \(x=\frac{d}{L}\), but not the distance \(d\), nor the contour length \(L\). Similarly, both in experiment and in the simulations, the temperature \(T\) is constant, as well as the persistence length \(p_L\). As a result, their quotient is constant and can be written as a single parameter \(p=\frac{k_BT}{p_L}\). Finally, as the inextensible chain can be viewed as a chain can be viewed as an extensible chain with its parameter \(k\rightarrow\infty\). This is, however, computationally uncomfortable and it is much better to operate with inverse of elasticity.

Therefore, the exact form of the methods used in the StretchMe package are as follows:

Marko-Siggia

(10)¶\[F(x;p,k) = p\left( \frac{1}{4\cdot\left(1 - x + kF)\right)^2} - \frac{1}{4} + x - kF \right)\]

This implicit function is calculated by forming a polynomial, cubic both in \(F\) and in \(x\):

(11)¶\[\begin{split}-\frac{F^3}{k^3}-\frac{F^3}{k^2 p}+\frac{3 F^2 x}{k^2}-\frac{2.25 F^2}{k^2}+\frac{2 F^2 x}{k p}-\frac{2 F^2}{k p}-\frac{3 F x^2}{k}+\frac{4.5 F x}{k}-\frac{1.5 F}{k}+\\ \frac{F x^2}{p}+\frac{2 F x}{p}-\frac{F}{p}+x^3-2.25 x^2+1.5 x = 0\end{split}\]

this allows for calculating both \(F(x;p,k)\) as the sole real, positive root of this polynomial, as well as \(x(F;p,k)\) as the sole real root lying within the interval \((0,1)\).

Stretch-adjusted

(12)¶\[F(x;p,k) = p\left( \frac{1}{4\cdot\left(1 - x\cdot(1-kF)\right)^2} - \frac{1}{4} + x\cdot(1-kF) \right)\]

with the exact values of \(F(x;p,k)\) and \(x(F;p,k)\) calculated as the roots of the polynomial:

(13)¶\[\begin{split}\frac{4 F^3 k^3 x^3}{b^3}+\frac{4 F^3 k^2 x^2}{b^2 p}-\frac{12 F^2 k^2 x^3}{b^2}+\frac{9 F^2 k^2 x^2}{b^2}-\frac{8 F^2 k x^2}{b p}+\frac{8 F^2 k x}{b p}+\frac{12 F k x^3}{b} + \\ -\frac{18 F k x^2}{b}+\frac{6 F k x}{b}+\frac{4 F x^2}{p}-\frac{8 F x}{p}+\frac{4 F}{p}-4 x^3+9 x^2-6 x = 0\end{split}\]
